chapter_title: Unity in Diversity, or ‘Many in the One’

questions.question_text: What is meant by ‘unity in diversity’ in the Indian scenario?
hints: Think about common elements across diverse cultural practices
Consider how different regions share underlying cultural threads

questions.question_text: What aspects of India’s diversity are the most striking?
How do we make out the unity underlying the diversity?
hints: Look for common themes across different practices

questions.question_text: As a class activity, make lists of (1) the birthplaces of at least 5 classmates and the birthplaces of their parents; (2) the students’ mother tongues and other languages known to them. Discuss the results in terms of diversity.
As a class activity, make a list of ingredients (grains, spices, etc.) that are used in your home.
Take any one vegetable and think of the number of different dishes you can prepare with it.
Explain how the example of the sari reflects both unity and diversity (in 100-150 words).
hints: Consider common features across all saris
Note regional variations in fabric, design, and draping styles

questions.question_text: In the above pictures, can you recognise what a sari has been used for?
Are you aware of, or can you imagine, more uses for the sari?
Following the example of the sari, make a list of different styles you have seen for the dhoti — both as regards the fabric and the uses the dhoti can be put to. What conclusion can you draw?
What is your favourite festival and how is it celebrated in your region? Do you know whether it is celebrated in any other part of India, maybe under a different name?
hints: Research festival names in different regions

questions.question_text: During October–November, many major festivals take place in India. Make a list of the few main ones and their various names in different parts of the country.
In a class discussion, try to identify the episode depicted in the painting shown in Fig. 8.6 above and important details associated with it.
hints: Analyze visual elements in the painting

questions.question_text: Conduct a class discussion on the two quotations at the start of the chapter.
Select a few stories from the Pañchatantra and discuss how their message is still valid today. Do you know of any similar stories from your region?
hints: Identify moral lessons in Panchatantra stories

questions.question_text: Collect a few folk tales from your region and discuss their message.
Is there any ancient story that you have seen being depicted through a form of art? It could be a sculpture, a painting, a dance performance, a movie … Discuss with your classmates.
hints: Recall temple sculptures or traditional paintings

questions.question_text: Discuss in class the following quotation by India’s first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, when he travelled to many parts of India before Independence: 'Everywhere I found a cultural background which had exerted a powerful influence on their lives. … The old epics of India, the Ramayana and the Mahabharata and other books, in popular translations and paraphrases, were widely known among the masses, and every incident and story and moral in them was engraved on the popular mind and gave a richness and content to it. Illiterate villagers would know hundreds of verses by heart and their conversation would be full of references to them or to some story with a moral, enshrined in some old classic.'
hints: Analyze Nehru's observations about epic influence
Discuss cultural unity through shared stories
